active_learning.discussion_prompt: Compare the security risks of file-based secret injection with environment variable injection and managed secret services like AWS Secrets Manager. Which method would you recommend for a production microservices architecture and why? Consider factors like persistence, discoverability, rotation ease, and compliance (e.g., OWASP, CIS Benchmarks).
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

layer.name: Layer 1
layer.content: Basic terms: Secrets (passwords, API keys); Secret Injection (delivery methods); File-Based (files mounted/read by apps). Risks: Persistence on disk, discoverability (e.g., 'find / -name *.key'), no auto-rotation.

layer.name: Layer 2
layer.content: File types (JSON, PEM, plain text); Mounting mechanisms (Kubernetes volumes: emptyDir/tmpfs, hostPath); Access controls (chmod 600, SELinux labels, pod security policies).

layer.name: Layer 3
layer.content: Step-by-step: 1) Create secret file (e.g., echo 'pass' > db.txt); 2) Kubernetes YAML: volumes: - name: secret-vol hostPath: /secrets; volumeMounts: mountPath: /app/secrets; 3) Server: Place in /var/secrets with init scripts.

layer.name: Layer 4
layer.content: Rotation (cron jobs + Vault dynamic secrets); Encryption at rest (Kubernetes etcd encryption, LUKS); Vault integration (Vault agent injector for file injection); Monitoring (audit logs for file access).

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education. Generate 20-25 high-quality flashcards on 'File-Based Secret Injection' (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > 001_Cryptography > 006_Key Management > 007_Secrets Management > Secrets Injection and Distribution > File-Based Secret Injection). Use the provided learning objectives, active learning components, scaffolding layers (including prior knowledge and big picture), and flashcard schema exactly. **Completed Research Context:** File-based secret injection stores secrets in files (e.g., mounted volumes in K8s). Risks: Disk persistence, runtime dumps (ps aux), no rotation, etcd exposure if misconfigured. Best practices: tmpfs, encryption (K8s 1.13+), Vault sidecar. Standards: OWASP Secrets Cheat Sheet (avoid files, centralize); Kubernetes Docs (encrypt etcd); Microsoft Cloud Security Benchmark (SC-12: Managed services over files); CIS K8s Benchmark (5.4.1: Encrypt secrets); NIST 800-53 (SC-12: Key mgmt). Sources: owasp.org/cheatsheets/Secrets_Management_Cheat_Sheet.html; kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/configuration/secret/; docs.aws.amazon.com/secretsmanager/; hashicorp/vault; cloudsecurityalliance.org; cisecurity.org/benchmark/kubernetes. Incorporate: Discussion/trade-offs, problem-solving scenarios, formative MCQs (e.g., 'Primary risk? A) Lacks rotation B) Base64 secure C) Easy mount D) etcd encrypted'). Ensure variety: 60% MCQ, 20% short answer, 20% scenario. Cover all Bloom's levels progressively via scaffolding layers. Output ONLY in JSON array of flashcards, each matching schema formats. No extra text.
